newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains cattle sales thin at $63 - feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains cattle sales thin at $63 - feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains cattle traded in light volume early Wednesday at $63.00 per cwt, unchanged from Tuesday's brisk activity, feedlot sources said.
About 1,000 head sold in the Texas Panhandle and western Oklahoma area following about 20,000 on Tuesday, they said. Week to date movement Wednesday was pegged near 75,000 there.

There were no reported sales in Kansas, with some bids at $62.00 to $63.00 passed by owners seeking $63.00 to $64.00, sources there said. Sales Tuesday in Kansas were near 50,000 head, which brought the weekly movement to about 65,000, they said.
Tuesday's active trade sold out showlists at some feedlots but owners lost about $10.00 to $35.00 per head to remain current, several feedlot sources said.
Beef continued to move well, but packers keep discounting prices to get the job done, they said.
"There's no incentive to keep the beef price up as long as they can buy cattle cheaper," a Panhandle source said.

Beef prices Tuesday tumbled $1.03 to $1.86 per cwt, with 361 fabricated loads reported sold, USDA said. Heavyweight choice beef was down $1.28 at $99.63, the lowest since April 9, USDA statistics showed.
